lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read a short text about vets and find key details such as what vets do.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Read text aloud. Ask: “What animals does the vet help?” “What does the vet do?” Students underline answers in the SB.
stretchStrategies: Real-Life Vet Report – Students write 2–3 sentences about a visit to the vet or invent a story:
The vet helps animals. She helps cats and dogs. She is kind.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can trace and write the letter combinations “ng” and “ck” to form simple words.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say and write “ng” and “ck” sounds: “sing,” “kick.” Students sort words by sound and trace letters in their notebooks.
stretchStrategies: Real-Life Vet Report – Students write 2–3 sentences about a visit to the vet or invent a story:
The vet helps animals. She helps cats and dogs. She is kind.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say what vets do and name some animals they help.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Show images of different vets and animals. Ask: “What do they do?” “Have you seen this?” Students respond using key vocabulary.
stretchStrategies: Real-Life Vet Report – Students write 2–3 sentences about a visit to the vet or invent a story:
The vet helps animals. She helps cats and dogs. She is kind.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
